entry.title: New rich text accordion variation and styling improvements

link.title: New rich text accordion variation and styling improvements

entry.content:
The 4.12.0 release of forms4health delivers a new variation of the rich text select control, along with styling improvements to the original rich text select control and the master child repeat.

Rich text select as accordion

In the designer you can change the rich text control into an accordion by going to the additional settings tab and changing the Display Type to Collapsible

Original rich text styling improvements

Master child repeat styling improvements

entry.title: Try out our new ‘annotated image’ control

link.title: Try out our new ‘annotated image’ control

entry.content:
The 4.10.0 release of forms4health delivers a new type of control that allows users to annotate an image - for instance to describe patient injuries on a body map, or to illustrate heart defects.

Adding an annotated image control to a form in the form designer

In the designer palette the building block author can choose the image they want for users to add annotations to.

Using the control

entry.title: Introducing a new ‘scribble’ control
entry.content:
The 4.9.0 release of forms4health delivers a new type of control that will allow form users to create a free form sketch / diagram of their choice. For instance this could be used to sketch ianatomical parts, adding labels etc. as part of a consultation or it could be used to allow patients to sketch an injury. We call this control scribble.

Adding a scribble control to a form in the form designer

Using the control

entry.title: Improvements to forms4health documentation
entry.content:
Welcome to the new look forms4health user guide and knowledge base mini-site. This site is still very new and there are undoubtedley gaps and additional things we can improve upon.

What do we hope the site will achieve?

We aim to provide a complete knowledge base on this site that will be a useful resource whether you are new to developing forms with forms4health or are quite experienced developing forms - here the site can act as a full reference guide and ensure you are getting the most out of the platform.

Feedback is welcome

As this site is always going to be a continual work in progress we would welcome feedback and/or notificaiton of typos etc that will go a long way to improving the documentation quality and utility of the site. If you have suggestions please use the contact form on the site and/or email us at support@airelogic.com.
